formulas.title: Formula (extracted text)
formulas.raw: Sample covariance matrix For \(n\) observations and \(p\) variables, the sample covariance between variables \(j\) and \(k\) is \[ s_{j k} = \frac{1}{n - 1} \sum_{i=1}^n (x_{i j} - \bar{x}_j)\,(x_{i k} - \bar{x}_k). \] The sample covariance matrix \(S\) collects all \(s_{j k}\) in a \(p \times p\) matrix. Dividing by \(n - 1\) gives an unbiased estimator of the population covariance when data are independent and identically distributed.

formulas.title: Formula (extracted text)
formulas.raw: Population covariance matrix If you can treat the data as the entire population, you may use \[ \sigma_{j k} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n (x_{i j} - \bar{x}_j)\,(x_{i k} - \bar{x}_k), \] i.e. divide by \(n\) instead of \(n - 1\). This is the population covariance.
